settings.heading: PPE Designed to
settings.sub_heading: Protect your warehouse and distribution center teams with durable, ergonomic, and high-visibility PPE built to withstand long shifts, heavy loads, and fast-paced operations.

settings.heading: U.S. Warehousing & Distribution Industry Overview
settings.description1: The warehousing and distribution industry has become a vital component of modern commerce, employing over 1.8 million workers in the U.S. and growing rapidly due to e-commerce, third-party logistics (3PL), and global supply chain demands. Facilities often run 24/7 operations, moving thousands of goods per hour using a mix of human labor and automation.
settings.description2: With this speed comes risk. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, warehouse workers face elevated rates of struck-by injuries, forklift collisions, repetitive strain, and falls—especially when PPE protocols are overlooked. In fact, warehousing ranks among the top 10 most hazardous industries for nonfatal injuries.

settings.description1:
U.S. Mining Industry Overview

The U.S. mining sector is a critical pillar of the economy—powering construction, energy, and manufacturing industries through the extraction of coal, metal ores, non-metallic minerals, and rare earths. With over 400,000 workers, this industry spans underground tunnels, open-pit quarries, strip mines, and processing plants in all climates and terrains.

Mining jobs rank among the most dangerous occupations in the country. Workers face immediate physical hazards like falling rock, heavy equipment, and machinery, along with long-term health risks including lung damage from respirable dust and hearing loss from constant high-decibel noise.
settings.description2:
According to the U.S. Mine Safety and Health Administration (MSHA):

  • Over 25,000 mining injuries occur annually in the U.S.
  • The most frequent incidents involve slips, trips, falls, and equipment-related trauma
  • Long-term exposure to noise and dust leads to irreversible occupational illnesses

Mining environments are unforgiving—and that’s why reliable, rugged PPE isn’t optional—it’s a life-critical investment.

settings.description:
U.S. Oil & Gas Industry Overview

The oil and gas industry is the lifeblood of the American economy—powering homes, vehicles, and businesses. It employs over 600,000 workers across upstream exploration, midstream transportation, and downstream refining. From shale fields in Texas to deepwater operations in the Gulf of Mexico, this sector is driven by innovation—but defined by danger.

According to the U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics, oil and gas consistently rank among the top industries for workplace fatalities, largely due to explosions, toxic chemical exposure, electrical hazards, and confined space entry. Even minor errors can lead to catastrophic results, making proper PPE not just a regulatory requirement—but a literal life-saver.

Workforce realities in oil & gas:

  • High turnover and contract-based crews require fast onboarding and easy-to-use PPE
  • Harsh climates, remote locations, and flammable environments are standard
  • One PPE failure can result in site shutdowns, fines, or tragedy

The Critical Role of PPE in Construction Safety

PPE (Personal Protective Equipment) is the last line of defense between a worker and serious injury—or worse. From hard hats and steel-toe boots to fall arrest harnesses and high-vis apparel, PPE saves lives every single day.

Some key stats that highlight the importance of PPE:

  • 60% of workers involved in eye injuries were not wearing any eye protection at the time of the incident (CDC).
  • According to OSHA, 70% of hand injuries could be prevented with proper gloves.
  • In cases where PPE was used improperly, nearly 80% of the injuries were due to failure to wear it correctly or consistently.

These numbers underscore one truth:|PPE only works if it’s high-quality, properly selected, and consistently used.

settings.heading: Falling boxes or improperly stacked inventory
Pallet jacks, forklifts, conveyor systems, and automation equipment
Repetitive lifting, bending, or twisting
Cold storage zones or poorly ventilated hot areas
Walking surface hazards from spills or uneven flooring
Low-visibility environments and shaft lighting failure
The Critical Role of PPE in Warehouse Safety
settings.sub_heading: PPE in warehousing is all about movement and protection. It must shield workers from slips, machinery, and manual handling injuries—while remaining light, breathable, and non-restrictive to match the pace of picking, packing, and loading.
settings.sub_heading1: Common warehouse hazards addressed by PPE:

settings.custom_description: ANSI 107 safety vests and jackets for forklift zones
Impact-resistant, grip-enhancing gloves for handling packages
Bump caps and hard hats for areas with low clearance or overhead storage
Lifting belts, knee pads, and anti-fatigue insoles

settings.heading: Comprehensive PPE Categories for Warehouse Teams
settings.sub_heading: Equip your workforce with task-specific, certified protection across every hazard zone.

settings.heading: OSHA 1910 Subparts E & I | PPE and walking/working surface safety
ANSI/ISEA 107-2020 | High-visibility safety apparel
NIOSH | Air filtration and dust mask ratings for warehouse air quality concerns
DOT/CSA Compliance | PPE support for DOT-regulated work and commercial driver safety
ASTM F2413 | Protective footwear standards
NFPA/ASTM FR Ratings | For welding, hot work, or blast zone operations
Ergonomic Guidelines for Manual Material Handling | From NIOSH and Liberty Mutual studies
Compliance & Certification You Can Trust

settings.question: What PPE is most important for warehouse employees?
settings.answer: Every warehouse team should be equipped with non-slip footwear, high-visibility vests, hand protection, and back support. Specific roles may also require bump caps or hearing protection near conveyors or machines.

settings.question: Are your safety vests ANSI-compliant for warehouse visibility requirements?
settings.answer: Yes. Our vests and jackets meet ANSI/ISEA 107 standards for high-visibility performance in indoor and outdoor warehouse environments—especially where forklifts or AGVs are active.

settings.question: Do you offer gloves that provide grip without sacrificing dexterity?
settings.answer: Absolutely. We offer grip-enhancing gloves with tactile surfaces, breathable liners, and abrasion protection—ideal for small-part handling or carton stacking.

settings.question: What kind of ergonomic support do you recommend for repetitive lifting tasks?
settings.answer: We recommend adjustable back supports, ergonomic wrist braces, and anti-fatigue mats—all of which help reduce strain during long shifts on concrete floors.

settings.question: Can your boots handle slippery warehouse floors or loading docks?
settings.answer: Yes. We supply ASTM-rated safety boots with slip-resistant outsoles, oil resistance, and composite toes that provide protection without metal detection issues.

settings.question: Do you provide PPE suitable for freezer or cold storage areas?
settings.answer: We carry cold-rated gloves, thermal liners, insulated boots, and jacket systems that provide full protection in environments down to -40°F.

settings.question: Is there a way to quickly outfit new hires or seasonal workers?
settings.answer: Yes. We offer pre-packed onboarding kits with essential gear—perfect for high-turnover operations or seasonal labor surges.

settings.question: Can we brand PPE with logos or use colors for different departments?
settings.answer: Yes. We provide logo imprinting, color-coded vest programs, and custom labeling options to support warehouse zoning and company branding.

settings.question: How can we ensure PPE compliance across shifts or multiple facilities?
settings.answer: We help you implement PPE compliance checklists, shift-based audit tools, and centralized reordering systems to maintain consistency across locations.

settings.question: Do you offer solutions for dusty or poorly ventilated areas?
settings.answer: Yes. We supply NIOSH-approved dust masks, respiratory filters, and airflow-focused PPE for warehouses with limited ventilation or airborne particulates.
